questions.text: How does the World Health Organization (WHO) define blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) VA < 3/60

Explanation:

NPCB Classification of Visual Impairment

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as:

Classification

Visual Acuity

Visual Impairment

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 in the better eye with available correction

Low Vision

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60

Economic Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60

Social Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60

Manifest Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light

Absolute Blindness

No perception of light


 

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".(Option A)

The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction

Option B,C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: According to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey conducted from 2015 to 2019, what is the leading cause of moderate to severe visual impairment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option B)

Explanation

According to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey (2015-2019), untreated cataract remains the leading cause of moderate to severe visual impairment. Cataracts, which cause the lens of the eye to become cloudy and impair vision, are particularly prevalent in older adults. When left untreated, cataracts can lead to significant visual impairment and blindness, making it a major contributor to visual disability worldwide.

 

Major Causes of Blindness in population aged ≥ 50 years

  • Cataract - 66.2%
  • Corneal opacity (including trachomatous)
  • Cataract surgical complications (including PCO)
  • Posterior segment disease (excluding DR & ARMD) (Option D ruled out)
  • Glaucoma (Option C ruled out)

 

Major Causes of Visual Impairment in population aged ≥ 50 years

  • Cataract - 71.2% (Option B)
  • Refractive error (Option A ruled out)
  • Cataract surgical complications (including PCO)

 

Major Causes of Blindness in population aged 0-49 years

  • Corneal opacity - 37.5
  • All globe/ CNS abnormality (Amblyopia)
  • Phthisis
  • Other/undetermined

 

Major Causes of Visual Impairment in population aged 0-49 years

  • Refractive error - 29.6
  • Cataract
  • All globe/ CNS abnormality (Amblyopia)
  • Corneal opacity

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Explanation:

The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency leading to Xerophthalmia. It can be prevented by timely vitamin A prophylaxis.

 

Blindness in India:

  • Overall most common cause of blindness/visual impairment (VI): Cataract
  • Most common preventable cause of blindness: Vitamin A deficiency
  • Most common cause of blindness in children: Vitamin A deficiency
  • Most common cause of VI in children: Refractive error
  • Other causes of blindness in children: Trachoma, Retinopathy of prematurity; Congenital cataract; Ophthalmia neonatorum.

questions.text: Which organism is most likely causing the infection in a 14-day-old neonate with bilateral conjunctivitis and lung infiltrates, as found in a chest X-ray performed at the outpatient department?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

Explanation:

A 14-day-old neonate with Bilateral conjunctivitis and pneumonia-like presentation is suggestive of Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Neonatal conjunctivitis is also known as Ophthalmia neonatorum.

 

Ophthalmia neonatorum:



 

Definition

  • Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis is a mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge from one or both eyes in the first month of life.
  • Any discharge, even watery, from a baby’s eyes in the first week of life must be viewed under suspicion as tears are not secreted so early in life.






 

Aetiology of ophthalmia neonatorum

Mode of infection:

  • Before birth:
    • Very rare through infected liquor amnii
  • During birth:
    • From an infected birth canal
  • After birth:
    • During the first bath of a newborn
    • Soiled clothes
    • Fingers with infected lochia
 

Source of infection:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Presents between 2-5 days of birth (Option B)
    • The discharge becomes mucopurulent and purulent quickly
    • Thick yellow pus and marked chemosis
    • Cornea seen at the bottom of a crater-like pit in severe cases
 
  • Chlamydia trachomatis:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Onset at 5-14 days after birth (Option C)
    • Serotypes D to K are the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries
    • Characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies are seen
    • Less severe inflammation
    • Purulent discharge +
 
  • Other causes:
    • Staphylococci/ Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A)
    • Gram-negative coliforms
    • Herpes simplex virus
    • Chemical: silver nitrate solution previously used for prophylaxis immediately after birth: erythema, chemosis, lid edema, and discharge within the first 24 hours after birth.
 

Prophylaxis

  • Antenatal measures:
    • Treatment of genital infections and care of mother
    • Surveillance of pregnant women for STDs
  • Natal measures:
    • Aseptic, sterile precautions to be followed during deliveries
    • Clean the infant’s closed lids with sterile cotton soaked in normal saline and dried
  • Post-natal measures:
    • Povidone-iodine 2.5% solution
    • If the mother is under suspicion, 1% tetracycline or 0.5% erythromycin eye ointment is used in the baby immediately after birth and watched for a week.
    • Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IM or IV single dose for infants born to mothers with untreated gonococcal infection.
  • Crede’s method:
    • Old method using 1% silver nitrate applied to infants' eyes right after birth
    • It is NOT used now as it can cause chemical neonatal conjunctivitis.

Diagnosis

Treatment

Neisseria gonorrhoea

Ceftriaxone IM, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

Chemical

Wash eyes, erythromycin ointment, observe

Other bacteria

Neomycin-bacitracin ointment, gentamicin, or tobramycin drops

Herpes simplex virus

Acyclovir 3% eye ointment, systemic acyclovir (systemic involvement)

Chlamydia trachomatis

Erythromycin or chlortetracycline eye ointment, oral erythromycin (systemic infection)

 

Incorrect options:

Streptococci (Option A) and Mycoplasma (Option D): Though they can cause conjunctivitis and pneumonia, it is very rare in the case of a newborn.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the SAFE strategy for trachoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Evaluation of control program

Explanation:

  • Evaluation of control program is NOT included in the SAFE strategy for Trachoma.

 

Diagnosis and Management of Trachoma:

Investigations

  • Micro-immunofluorescence (micro-IF): Using pooled antigens; For routine diagnostic purposes
  • Culture of C. trachomatis: In irradiated McCoy cells; Expensive
  • Monoclonal antibody direct tests: IgA-IPA light microscopy tests are the best combination for diagnosis

Management (SAFE strategy)

 

SAFE is a WHO-recommended combination of interventions to treat trachoma and prevent it from leading to blindness

  • Surgery for cicatricial entropion and trichiasis (Tertiary prevention)
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism (Secondary prevention)
  • Facial cleanliness to avoid infection (Primary prevention)
  • Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation (Primordial prevention)

Surgery (Tertiary prevention) (Option B)

Epilation/ Bilamellar tarsal rotation

Antibiotics (Secondary prevention) (Option A)
  • For areas with 10% or more prevalence of active trachoma (TF in children 1-9 yrs): Azithromycin single oral dose 20 mg/kg to all community members
  • 5% to 10% prevalence: Antibiotic therapy targeted in the family and close contact only
  • Less than 5% prevalence: Only patients are treated

Facial cleanliness (Primary prevention) (Option D)

Frequent face wash with clean water, Avoid common towels, handkerchiefs, Surma rods, etc

Environmental improvement (Primordial prevention) (Option C)

Water latrines and good water supply to reduce flies, Sprays to control flies, Health education

questions.text: Vision 20/20- Which was added recently in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D.

In India, the recent addition to the Vision 20/20 program is "Refractive error and low vision." The Vision 20/20 program is a government initiative in India aimed at eliminating avoidable blindness and achieving the goal of "Vision 2020: The Right to Sight." The program focuses on addressing various causes of visual impairment and implementing strategies for prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Cataract: Cataract has been a longstanding focus in the Vision 20/20 program in India, with efforts made to increase access to cataract surgeries and reduce cataract-related blindness. It is not the recent addition to the program.

Option B. Childhood blindness: Although childhood blindness is an important concern, it is not the recent addition to the Vision 20/20 program in India. The program has long recognized the need for addressing childhood blindness and implementing interventions such as Vitamin A supplementation and pediatric eye care services.

Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma is a significant cause of visual impairment and blindness, but it is not the recent addition to the Vision 20/20 program in India. Efforts to raise awareness, improve early detection, and provide appropriate treatment for glaucoma have been ongoing for some time.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cataract:
